zuul/scheduler.py.message:
I think we need to handle this without relying on a periodic cleanup.  We need to release nodes and semaphores immediately when we cancel jobs during a reconfiguration.

At a high level, we know every time we're going to cancel a job because we're removing the pipeline or tenant, so when we do that, we should delete the zk node record which will instruct the executor to abort the job.  Once we have builds in ZK, we should also have the executor holding the lock on the nodes, so once it is finished aborting, it can release the node lock which will return the nodes to nodepool.  But maybe that's not in the first step of implementation, so until then, we'll want to release the nodes in the scheduler too.  I'm not sure it's practical for the executors to manage semaphores, so we'll probably want to continue to release them in the scheduler as well.

In short: for this change we need to actively cancel jobs, return nodes, and release semaphores when we cancel jobs for tenants or pipelines that are deleted.  And we know that none of the events from the executor for those builds will be processed, because they weren't processed before we canceled the job, and we know there won't be a result processor for that pipeline/tenant after we finish canceling the job.  So we know that we can take responsibility for them.

Later, we might be able to drop the special handling of returning nodepool nodes.

Just a note: We should still make sure the build is canceled in the future, even if the mechanism is different.  However it happens, we don't want it running after this point since it's effectively orphaned.

An actual concern: I think semaphores may not be handled in the case a pipeline or tenant is removed.  This method shares some code with scheduler.cancelJob, and that does return semaphores.  Perhaps we could use that instead of this?  Or otherwise somehow merge this code path?

Okay, deleting the build from zk directly sounds like a potentially good solution.

We still have some issues we need to address:

1) The comment above is a little misleading -- it's not really to fix the tests, it fixes a real problem that the tests are showing us.

2) We still need to deal with semaphores.

3) This shares a lot in common with https://review.opendev.org/785536 which effectively changes reconfigurations so that the only things they can mutate are deleting pipelines or tenants.  I think we should rebase on top of that change (actually https://review.opendev.org/786744 which is the end of that stack) and work from there.

Once we rebase, we'll still have to address the conflict you point out: that sometimes we call cancelJob when a tenant+pipeline still exists, and sometimes we call it when we're deleting it.

If it's complicated to resolve that issue, and in the very next change we're going to move the build requests into ZK as well which makes the issue moot, then we may want to review those changes together (we don't need to squash them, we can leave them as two changes) and just make sure we merge them together.

If we can resolve it with a temporary method like this one, that's fine too.

To summarise:

* Rebase on 786744
* Analyze the pipeline/tenant cleanup situation in that case
  * If it's not too difficult to resolve, keep this as a standalone change (we need to handle semaphores too).
  * Otherwise, do something hacky to make the tests pass but review it with the next change and merge them together.

I tried that out, but it looks like cancelJob() is only returning the nodeset in case the build wasn't running. I think in case the build was running the "normal" mechanism is used when the build result event is processed. However, with the result events in ZK, the scheduler won't process any results for deleted pipelines/tenants anymore. That might also be the reason why I didn't use cancelJob() here in the first place and only called the relevant parts (deleting the entry in self.executor.builds and returnung the nodeset) directly. So maybe we should simply call the tenant.semaphore_handler.release(item, job) in here to also handle semaphores.

Regarding the "orphaned builds": In the builds API change I simply delete the build in ZooKeeper directly (rather than invoking a cancel on the build) because the cancel event can't be processed anymore (see the comments in this method). The executor server listens for deleted build nodes and aborts the build in that case. The result would be the same as the executor server will then put a cancel event in the queue which isn't processed anymore, but IMHO it's a little more specific to simply delete the build (and return the nodeset) in here as this is all we need.

1) I can adapt the comment. I just wanted to write down what I saw so that at least somebody understands what this is all about in the first place.

2) I can re-use the line that returns the semaphores in the cancelJob() method. I'm just not sure if that is enough or if there is something else to address since I'm not familiar with semaphores at all.

3) Regarding your concern here
> Once we rebase, we'll still have to address the conflict you point out: that sometimes we call cancelJob when a tenant+pipeline still exists, and sometimes we call it when we're deleting it.

I think we need to implement some periodic cleanup for most of the ZooKeeper stuff. This could then also deal with that use case. Apart from this I think it's quite difficult to solve this issue as there could always be a race between the reconfiguration and a running job (unless we ensure that all jobs are finished before the reconfig starts, but I think this is rather difficult and not what we want). We might also be able to process the result events from all tenants/pipelines (not just the active ones), but that doesn't sound right. IMHO it wouldn't make much sense to process those results since nobody would be able to use them.
I'd rather not rename things like that on import without a good reason; it makes grepping difficult or impossible.  We should probably rename it in the original to make it more clear.
The import above is for TENANT_ROOT not TENANT_EVENT_ROOT.

I did the following import in my version of the change:

from zuul.zk.event_queues import TENANT_ROOT as TENANT_EVENT_ROOT

The main reason was to make the delete part that uses this variable further down a little more understandable. We are not removing the whole tenant there, but just the event queues in ZooKeeper. Maybe we will change the variable name in the event_queues module later on as well, but I didn't want to do this in here.
Any concern that a busy tenant could starve the others? Maybe we should consider a breadth first approach? I though I suspect depth first like this is better most of the time.

When there are multiple schedulers, we'll lock for processing at the pipeline level.  So this is probably the way to go to be most efficient then.  And of course, if there is starvation in that case, another scheduler can be added.

Also, I think since we get the event list at the start of the iterator, we'll eventually move on to other pipelines and tenants, so a busy tenant could cause other tenants to 'pause' but not completely starve them.

I think this is a straight copy from the existing executor client and not a change in logic.

Regardless, I think this is correct -- an executor crashing shouldn't penalize the job.
Shouldn't this be subject to the build.job.attempts upper limit of retries too?
Yes the whole result event handling is just copy/move of the existing parts from different places. I did just a few adaptions to make the parts work together in a single place.

snap-overlay/templates/nginx.conf.j2.message:
I propose we use image_size_cap instead:

https://docs.openstack.org/glance/latest/configuration/configuring.html#configuring-glance-image-size-limit

and set client_max_body_size to 0 (disabling it).

https://nginx.org/en/docs/http/ngx_http_core_module.html#client_max_body_size
"Setting size to 0 disables checking of client request body size."

Rather than make it complicated, if we set client_max_body_size to 0 and effectively disable it we adopt the image_size_cap defaults in glance. This allows the user to configure it via glance  config.

try to write more descriptive commit messages (it's a must in case of more complicated reviews).
Commit message should include details so that a reviewer can quickly understand the context of the change, why it's need, what it fixes, ... all this will help reviewers to review.

In this case I'd write a commit message like this:

```
Fixing coverage issue

job, openstack-cover-jobs, to run the coverage in Zuul.
```

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ma.message: Has the removal of this been verified by increasing drbd filesystem size by a very large amount such that it may take much more than 10 seconds (i.e. even several minutes) to sync?   After such a drbd resize operation, please also perform host-swact/host-lock/host-unlock and check the lvs vs drbd sizes to ensure there are no issue

Thanks Mihnea, I would also recommend this to be verified with other drbd filesystems which may be more likely in use, such as psql (postgres) and drbd-platform.  And that this is ok following initial bootstrap and deployment as well.
Isn't the check for "Connected" here enough ?  https://opendev.org/starlingx/config/src/branch/master/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/manager.py#L8794
I've just done a test with system controllerfs-modify extension="250", it took ~30 min and everything it's looking good after I did some swacts/locks.

I'm a little concerned about pulling this gating mechanism here. There are a myriad of connection states: https://linbit.com/drbd-user-guide/users-guide-drbd-8-4/#s-connection-states. Might is be safer to just check for the "Connected" state here too?
Updated the review to check for 'Connected' states here and re-tested the same scenarios.

I was actually thinking that we just add the Connected state to the existing checks:

("SyncSource" in row or "PausedSyncS" in row or "Connected" in row)

This turned out not to be reliable. David is currently reworking this in the following review: https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/ansible-playbooks/+/784860

Do we need to do the same thing here?

That would be my recommendation. I also suggest moving away from using drbd-overview (which uses df for filesystem size). There's an overhead that's included in the df size calculations that may give poor results for larger filesystems. We should probably use dumpe2fs or similar and get the actual block count.
Extend comment for reason to check "Connected"

I see where you are coming from Al, we've changed the sync behavior in the past, but typically haven't moved the devices in around. It's more adding or removing specific devices, which in that case we'd have to re-evaluate this code. I'm all for adding an addition SB to optimize this, but should probably fix this as we have installs where the resizing never finishes.

I agree with Sergii here, there is not really a need to have two different options if you think about it...we never run update and upgrade in the same job and if we run the validations it doens't matter if it's for upgrades or updates. Also, by having a single option we reduce the number of options in the plugin, which is pretty long at the moment. templates/pre-upgrade-osp13-validation.s.message:
I would introduce timeout here, very similar to what we do in templates/node_upgrade_post.sh.j2

elapsed_seconds=0
timeout_seconds=600
while [ $(openstack workflow execution show $ID -f value -c State) == "RUNNING" ]; do
    sleep 1
    (( elapsed_seconds += 1 ))
    echo "Waiting for validation to complete"
    if [ $elapsed_seconds -ge $timeout_seconds ]; then
        echo "FAILURE:  Validation didn't finish within ${timeout_seconds} seconds"
        exit 1
    fi
done

      mgr 'allow rw' \
      mon 'allow r'

I understand what you are saying here, but it may be a little hard for someone who is not familiar with the change. Can we rephrase so it is easier for the reader? I'm thinking of something like:


Added an active wait in the method "Backend.lookup". 

With this change, optional RowEventHandler and timeout parameters can be used to wait and/or retry.

If a timeout and a RowEventHandler instance listening on the same IDL connection are provided and the "lookup" method does not find the requested register, a WaitEvent instance related to the
table and register requested is created. Once the wait event returns, the method tries the lookup once again. If the lookup is still unable to find a match, "RowNotFound" exception is raised or the default value is returned.
I'll add the first description sentence you wrote.
nit: This isn't true anymore with using the cached result from the Event, but not a big deal.

ovsdbapp/backend/ovs_idl/__init__.py.message: I think if wait() returns False, we'd need to unwatch the event. If the event is found, it being a ONETIME event, it'll get removed. But if it isn't, I think it might stick around indefinitely.
That was my point. I think we *will* have an endless list of watched events if we *don't* unwatch the event if wait() returns false.
Actually I think I should remove it always, regardless of the result. We don't want to have, in the IDL, an endless list of watched events
Lookup looks up by UUID or name. The condition is going to have to be a custom match_fn that does a lookup() call.
Right, I forgot the name. Thanks!

If we do this with finally, I think we'll potentially unwatch the event twice if the event actually fires. WaitEvent is a onetime event, so will remove the event itself when it matches. I think you'd have to do something like:

 notify_handler.watch_event(wait_event)
 if not wait_event.wait():
     notify_handler.unwatch_event(wait_event)

We use sets/discard() in the implementation, so I don't think anything bad will happen if we do call it twice. But if we are going to rely on that behavior, we should probably document it so we know not to change that behavior in the future.
Ahhhh yes, thanks. I'll implement this as you suggested.

Since the event itself actually needs to do a lookup() to know if it matches, we could avoid doing an additional lookup() at the end.

I worked up a PoC of what I think the patch would need to do, but I've not tested other than verifying it doesn't break existing tests and that doing a lookup for something bogus delays for the timeout. It also tries to detect the notify_handler if it lives at the place where it often does by convention. Since we're changing the API a bit, maybe we can document something like an optional API.notify_handler attribute? https://paste.centos.org/view/cf87e7f0

It should be noted that the event.match() which is now lookup() is going to be called for every CREATE event on whatever table we register it for, and this could be expensive-ish. lookup() should be O(1) or ~O(log n) since it is a uuid dict lookup or looking up by indexed objects. You'd definitely not want lookup() with timeout set called while importing the initial database or something. :p I'm not really sure whether the WaitEvent strategy or retrying with backoff is the best solution. WaitEvent should be more responsive, there's a chance for it being more expensive.

Thanks for the code. I'll implement it and I'll document this API change.

About the cost of this method, I'm not sure about what could happen during the initialization. Actually this is something that should handled in the client, something like having a lock set until a full initialization is done.

I think, as you said, a wait event should be more responsive in most of the cases. Actually, this is an exceptional case, when we know a register should be there in the DB and is not in the local cache. In any case, this functionality should be implemented in the client (Neutron, for example) with care and short timeouts (less than 2-3 seconds).

I'm not sure about how to document it. This should came from an IDL connection but this is not a required parameter in ovs.IDL or connection.OvsdbIdl (based on the first one, Neutron clients inherit from it).

I would keep it in this way: provide the handler; if not, try to get the attribute and if that doesn't work, we won't use it.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Still WIP?
Is this still the case?

the change has merged to SQLAlchemy master and will by all accounts be part SQLAlchemy 1.4 starting with the beta releases.

so the simple answer is, "no, this is not WIP anymore".

The more complex answer is where I'm kind of inviting people to look at the upstream change as I haven't gotten much feedback on it, both in terms of a breaking change being made as well as the proposed (and now implemented) API design.

I try to stay away from breaking changes as much as possible but I made an exception here.  I was expecting some skepticism but everyone I asked seemed OK with it and nobody has said much about the new API.

Background on the change is published at https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/changelog/migration_14.html#the-url-object-is-now-immutable and the URL class documentation is at https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/core/engines.html#sqlalchemy.engine.URL . pkg/phase/ifc/helper.go.message: Please, let's avoid this change. All methods here accept IDs, it is easier to use this way.

Phase interfaces (helper, phase, executor, client) were designed to be used by command line and as go library. And I believe they make command line and library simple integration and straightforward.

Helper interface is designed to help interact with bundle document set and config. So that anyone who wants to get information about any document can do so easily. It wasn't designed and shouldn't be designed around speed of execution (but speed is always nice).

In the command line interface, in the next iteration we will be working on making airshipctl easier to use and debug. so we may add command `airshipctl phase executor` which would allow user to quickly get information what is the final view of the executor (after kustomizations). And it would be very convenient for the developer and reviewers to simply add and read such code:


func (c *PhaseExecutorCommand) Run() error{
     ...
     helper := phase.NewHelper
     ...

     execDoc, err := helper.ExecutorDoc(c.Options.PhaseID)
     printExecutorDoc(o.Writer, execDoc)
}

The developer would be abstracted and would not need to know that he has to get a phase object first. This is why Helper works with IDs.

Also, this method is used by airshipui: https://github.com/airshipit/airshipui/blob/d4d8e0174a8ef8612d8ebd1d3be9246512e26e4c/pkg/ctl/phase.go#L144-L148

And they would have to do extra work of getting phase object.

Interfaces should not be modified to optimize internal process, instead optimize in private functions.

But if you really want to optimize let's keep it outside this patchset. Because optimization discussion can interfere with our goal of making validation work.

Well, I can restore it to original signature, but I would ask you once again to take a look inside of ExecutorDoc function before making final decision. I changed it to this approach since ExecutorDoc anyway uses v1alpha1.Phase object inside to generate executorDocument [1], IMO, it makes completely no sense to pass inside this function phaseID and then search a phase in a bundle and convert it into the same v1alpha1 phase. This step is completely redundant and unnecessary since all the calls of ExecutorDoc (except unit tests) are performed from phase object, where we have handy v1alpha1.Phase object which we can conveniently pass there. Therefore, I personally disagree with your point, sorry, and I very much ask you to listen my arguments. 


[1] https://github.com/airshipit/airshipctl/blob/master/pkg/phase/helper.go#L274-L297

All right, I'll keep it out from this PS and leave this question for future discussions since this particular change is not essential anymore to make validation work (we moved to different approach to retrieve validator executor). I have couple of ideas to satisfy both your and my requirements regarding this use-case, but that's not the topic for this PS.

neutron/tests/unit/conf/policies/test_ag.message:
The different scope types kind of highlight the issues in defining `is_admin` as a valid way to escalate privileges. For example, we can now have project administrators, domain administrators, and system administrators and they may or may not be able to do the same things.

I'd recommend building context objects to be more representative of the tokens we're modeling.

  self.system_admin_context = context.Context(
      user=fake_user_id,
      roles=['admin', 'member', 'reader'],
      system_scope='all'
  )
  self.system_member_context = context.Context(
      user=fake_user_id,
      roles=['member', 'reader'],
      system_scope='all'
  )
  self.system_reader_context = context.Context(
      user=fake_user_id,
      roles=['reader'],
      system_scope='all'
  )


We can take the same approach with project personas:

  self.project_admin_context = context.Context(
      user=fake_user_id,
      roles=['admin', 'member', 'reader'],
      project_id=self.project_id
  )
  self.project_member_context = context.Context(
      user=fake_user_id,
      roles=['member', 'reader'],
      project_id=self.project_id
  )
  self.project_reader_context = context.Context(
      user=fake_user_id,
      roles=['reader'],
      project_id=self.project_id
  )

I've modified the above roles to include a list, which is realistic of what will happen if you get a token from keystone, process it with keystonemiddleware, and then create a context object from the request environment.

[0] https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib/src/commit/8c626fe039a5c32e26710b8e8b6d53a4ac6a11b7/neutron_lib/context.py

This testing approach will work fine for exercising situations that don't require modified API code. For example, if neutron's API filters ports by project ID, then a more comprehensive test might be a functional API test.

This might be a naive question, but does neutron have any code elsewhere in the API that handles authorization outcomes? 

For example, a project user only expects to see networks accessible to their network when they list networks. How much of that behavior is driven by the oslo.policy engine and policies themselves?

I know neutron-lib has some database-layer scoping logic based on the context object, but is that it?

It looks like this should work:

kubectl wait --timeout=180 --for=condition=Established \
  crd/clusterissuers.cert-manager.io \
  crd/issuers.cert-manager.io \
  crd/certificaterequests.cert-manager.io \
  crd/certificates.cert-manager.io

can we also validate rollout of the cert-manager deployment:

kubectl rollout status --timeout=180 -n cert-manager deployment/cert-manager
